Undid revision 857823482 by [[Special:Contributions/45.126.20.34|45.126.20.34]] ([[User talk:45.126.20.34|talk]]) Reverted edits. The information has a source which supports the information. You changing it here is not going to change reality.
revision.text:
{{Citations missing|date=March 2010}}
[[File:Daikokuten - color.jpg|thumb|upright|Daikokuten]] [[Image:Daikoku.jpg|thumb|right|Daikoku, God of Wealth|upright]] In [[Japan]], '''Daikokuten''' ([[wiktionary:大黒天|大黒天]]), the god of great darkness or blackness, or the god of five cereals, is one of the [[Seven Lucky Gods]] (''Fukujin''). Daikokuten evolved from the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] form of the [[Deva (Hinduism)|Indian deity]] [[Shiva]] [[Shinbutsu-shūgō|intertwined]] with the [[Shinto]] god [[Ōkuninushi]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Jeremy|last=Roberts|title=Japanese Mythology A to Z|publisher=Infobase Publishing|year=2009|page=28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdfgjV2kw6oC}}</ref> The name is the Japanese equivalent of '''[[Mahākāla]]''', the Hindu name for Shiva.<ref>{{cite book|first=Pratapaditya|last=Pal|title=Indian Sculpture: 700-1800|publisher=Los Angeles County Museum of Art|page=180}}</ref>
The god enjoys an exalted position as a household deity in Japan. Daikoku's association with wealth and prosperity precipitated a custom known as ''fukunusubi'', or "theft of fortune". This custom started with the belief that whoever stole divine figures was assured of good fortune if not caught in the act. The ''toshi-no-ichi'' (year-end market) held at [[Sensō-ji]] became the main venue of the sale and disposal of such images by the fortune-seekers. Many small stalls were opened where articles including images of Daikoku were sold on the eve of New Year celebrations.<ref name="Thakur1986">{{cite book|last=Thakur|first=Upendra|title=Some Aspects of Asian History and Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m42TldA_OvAC&pg=PA190|year=1986|publisher=Abhinav Publications|isbn=978-81-7017-207-9|page=190}}</ref>
The Japanese also maintain the symbol of Mahakala as a monogram. The traditional pilgrims climbing the holy [[Mount Ontake]] wear [[tenugui]] (a kind of white scarf) with the [[Bīja|seed syllable]] of Mahakala.
Daikoku is variously considered to be the god of wealth, or of the household, particularly the kitchen. He is recognised by his wide face, smile, and a flat black hat. He is often portrayed holding a golden [[mallet]] called ''[[Uchide no kozuchi]]'', otherwise known as the "mallet of fortune", and is seen seated on bales of [[rice]], with [[Rat|rats]] nearby signifying plentiful food.
Daikoku's image was featured on the first Japanese bank note, designed by [[Edoardo Chiossone]].
==Goddess Daikokutennyo== The [[Butsuzōzui|Butsuzōzui compendium]] of 1690 (reprinted and expanded in 1796) lists and illustrates six different manifestations of Daikoku, including the feminine form known as Daikokunyo (大黒女) ("She of the Great Blackness") or Daikokutennyo (大黒天女) ("She of the Great Blackness of the Heavens").<ref name="Butsuzōzui059">{{cite web|title=Butsuzōzui (Illustrated Compendium of Buddhist Images)|url=http://www.lib.ehime-u.ac.jp/SUZUKA/316/index.html|location=Ehime University Library|page=(059.jpg)|language=Japanese|format=digital photos|date=1796}}</ref> As Daikoku is the [[wiktionary:nipponize|nipponized]] form of the masculine [[Mahākāla]], Daikokutennyo is the nipponized form of the feminine [[Mahakali|Mahākāli]].
When Daikoku is regarded as the feminine Daikokutennyo<ref name="Butsuzōzui059"></ref> and [[Kisshōten|Kisshoutennyo]] is counted among the [[Seven_Lucky_Gods|seven Fukujin]],<ref name="Butsuzōzui077">{{cite web|title=Butsuzōzui (Illustrated Compendium of Buddhist Images)|url=http://www.lib.ehime-u.ac.jp/SUZUKA/316/index.html|location=Ehime University Library|page=(077.jpg)|language=Japanese|format=digital photos|date=1796}}</ref> all three of the Hindu [[Tridevi]] goddesses are represented among the Fukujin.
==See also== *[[Mahākāla]] *[[Mahakali|Mahākāli]] *[[Seven_Lucky_Gods|Fukujin (福神) deities]] *[[Japanese_Buddhist_pantheon#Level_4:_Heavenly_deities_.28Ten-bu.29|Buddhist Tenbu (天部) deities]] *[[Shinbutsu-shūgō|Shinto-Buddhism syncretism]] *[[Hinduism in Japan]] *[[Marici (Buddhism)]]
==References==
<references/> *Japan and Indian Asia by Hajime Nakamura. Publisher: Firma KLM, 1961. Publication Date: 1961 *India and Japan: A Study in interaction during 5th cent - 14th century - By Upendra Thakur .
==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160728064135/http://www.buddah-blade.com/Is_Mahakala/is_mahakali.html Modern depiction of Daikokuten and Daikokutennyo] by Japanese artist Sekishō (石商)

{{Japan-myth-stub}}

{{Infobox writer | name = Edward Abbey | image = Edward Abbey.jpg | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1927|1|29}} | birth_place = [[Indiana, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1989|3|14|1927|1|29}} | death_place = [[Tucson, Arizona]], U.S. | occupation = Essayist, novelist | genre = | movement = | notableworks = ''[[Desert Solitaire]]''
''[[The Monkey Wrench Gang]]'' | influences = | influenced = }} '''Edward Paul Abbey''' (January 29, 1927 – March 14, 1989) was an American author and essayist noted for his advocacy of [[environmentalism|environmental issues]], criticism of [[public land]] policies, and [[anarchist]] political views. His best-known works include the [[novel]] ''[[The Monkey Wrench Gang]]'', which has been cited as an inspiration by environmental groups, and the non-fiction work ''[[Desert Solitaire]]''. ==Early life and education== Abbey was born in [[Indiana, Pennsylvania]], on January 29, 1927 to Mildred Postlewait and Paul Revere Abbey. Mildred was a schoolteacher and a church organist, and gave Abbey an appreciation for classical music and literature. Paul was a [[socialist]], [[anarchist]], and [[atheist]] whose views strongly influenced Abbey.{{cite book |editor1-last=Mongillo |editor1-first=John |editor2-last=Booth |editor2-first=Bibi |title=Environmental Activists |date=2001 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport CT |isbn=0313308845 |url=https://books.google.co.th/books?id=n42Rf_ibaMcC&pg=PA1&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=15 July 2018}}{{RP|1}} Abbey graduated from [[high school]] in Indiana, Pennsylvania, in 1945. Eight months before his 18th birthday, when he would be faced with being [[Conscription|drafted]] into the [[United States military]], Abbey decided to explore the American southwest. He traveled by foot, bus, [[hitchhiking]], and [[freight train hopping]]. During this trip he fell in love with the [[desert]] country of the [[Four Corners]] region. Abbey wrote: "[...]crags and pinnacles of naked rock, the dark cores of ancient [[volcanoes]], a vast and silent emptiness smoldering with heat, color, and indecipherable significance, above which floated a small number of pure, clear, hard-edged clouds. For the first time, I felt I was getting close to the West of my deepest imaginings, the place where the tangible and the mythical became the same."{{cite book|author=Ronald, Ann|title=The New West of Edward Abbey|publisher=University of Nevada Press|year=1982|isbn=0874173574|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=th4RcKPOldMC&pg=PA59}}{{RP|59}}{{cite book|author=Western Literature Association|chapter=Edward Abbey|title=A Literary history of the American West|publisher=TCU Press|year=1987|isbn=978-0-87565-021-0|page=604|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AFfqbTjG7OkC&pg=PA604}}For Abbey's full account of this trip, see his essay [https://books.google.com/books?id=zU4yQmhETbQC&pg=PA22 "Hallelujah on the Bum"] In the military Abbey had applied for a clerk typist position but instead served two years as a [[military police officer]] in Italy. Abbey was promoted in the military twice but, due to his knack for opposing authority, was twice demoted and was [[honorably discharged]]{{cite book|author=Peterson, David|title=Confessions of a barbarian: selections from the journals of Edward Abbey|publisher=Big Earth Publishing|year=2003|isbn=978-1-55566-287-5|page=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VRueIqU-kSIC&pg=PA1}} as a private. His experience with the military left him with a distrust for large institutions and regulations which influenced his writing throughout his career, and strengthened his anarchist beliefs.{{cite book |last1=Bishop, Jr |first1=James |title=Epitaph for a Desert Anarchist; The Life and Legacy of Edward Abbey |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=0684804395 |edition=1st Touchstone |url=https://books.google.co.th/books?id=pXSC0AnpzLkC&pg=PA88&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=15 July 2018}} When he returned to the United States, Abbey took advantage of the [[G.I. Bill]] to attend the [[University of New Mexico]], where he received a B.A. in philosophy and English in 1951, and a [[master's degree]] in philosophy in 1956.{{RP|247}} During his time in college, Abbey supported himself by working at a variety of odd jobs, including being a newspaper reporter and [[bartending]] in [[Taos, New Mexico]]. During this time he had few male friends but had intimate relationships with a number of women. Shortly before getting his bachelor's degree, Abbey married his first wife, Jean Schmechal (another UNM student).{{RP|88-89}} While an undergraduate, Abbey was the editor of a student newspaper in which he published an article titled "Some Implications of Anarchy". A cover quotation (from [[Voltaire]] of the article, "ironically attributed to [[Louisa May Alcott]]", stated: "Man will never be free until the last king is strangled with the entrails of the last priest." University officials seized all of the copies of the issue and removed Abbey from the editorship of the paper.{{Cite book|author=Scheese, Don|title=Nature writing: the pastoral impulse in America|publisher=Psychology Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-415-93889-1|page=108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6gLPRqD0NR4C&pg=PA108}} Upon receiving his honorable discharge papers, Abbey sent them back to the department with the words "Return to Sender". The [[FBI]] took note and added a note to his file which was opened in 1947 when Edward Abbey committed an act of civil disobedience; he posted a letter while in college urging people to rid themselves of their [[draft card]]s.{{cite web|url=http://vault.fbi.gov/Edward%20Abbey|title=Edward Abbey|publisher=vault.fbi.org}} Abbey was on the FBI's watch-list ever since then and was watched throughout his life. In 1952 Abbey wrote a letter against the draft in times of peace, and again the FBI took notice writing, "Edward Abbey is against war and military." Throughout Abbey's life the FBI took notes building a profile on Abbey, observing his movements, and interviewing many people who knew him. Towards the later part of his life Abbey learned of the FBI's interest in him and said, "I'd be insulted if they weren't watching me." After graduating, Schmechal and Abbey traveled together to [[Edinburgh, Scotland]], where Abbey spent a year at [[Edinburgh University]] as a [[Fulbright scholar]].{{RP|247}} During this time, Abbey and Schmechal separated and ended their marriage. In 1951, Abbey began an affair with Rita Deanin,{{cite book|editor=Peterson, David|author=Abbey, Edward|title=Confessions of a barbarian: selections from the journals of Edward Abbey|publisher=Big Earth Publishing|year=2003|isbn=978-1-55566-287-5|page=126|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VRueIqU-kSIC&pg=PA126}} who in 1952 would become his second wife after he and Schmechal divorced. Deanin and Abbey had two children, Joshua N. Abbey and Aaron Paul Abbey.{{Cite book|editor=Macrae, John|title=The Serpents of Paradise: A Reader|publisher=Macmillan|year=1996|isbn=978-0-8050-3133-1|page=57|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zU4yQmhETbQC&pg=PA57}} Abbey's [[master's thesis]] explored [[anarchism]] and the [[morality of violence]], asking the two questions: "To what extent is the current [[Anarchism and violence|association between anarchism and violence]] warranted?" and "In so far as the association is a valid one, what arguments have the anarchists presented, explicitly or implicitly, to justify the use of violence?"{{cite book|author=Phillipon, Daniel J.|chapter=Toward Ecotopia: Edward Abbey and Earth First!|title=Conserving Words: How American Nature Writers Shaped the Environmental Movement|publisher=University of Georgia Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-8203-2759-4|pages=225–226|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EMB7Sr0UGxUC&pg=PA225}} After receiving his master's degree, Abbey spent 1957 at [[Stanford University]] on a [[Wallace Stegner Creative Writing Fellowship]].{{RP|247}} ==Work for National Park Service== [[File:Double O Arch-Arches NP-Utah.jpg|thumb|right|Abbey spent time as a park ranger at what became [[Arches National Park]] near [[Moab, Utah]]]] In 1956 and 1957, Abbey worked as a seasonal [[Park ranger|ranger]] for the [[United States National Park Service]] at [[Arches National Monument]] (now a national park), near the town of [[Moab, Utah]]. Abbey held the position from April to September each year, during which time he maintained trails, greeted visitors, and collected campground fees. He lived in a house trailer that had been provided to him by the Park Service, as well as in a [[Ramada (shelter)|ramada]] that he built himself. During his stay at Arches, Abbey accumulated a large volume of notes and sketches which later formed the basis of his first non-fiction work, ''[[Desert Solitaire]]''.{{cite book|author=Scheese, Don|chapter=Desert Solitaire: Counter-Friction to the Machine in the Garden|editors=Glotfelty, Cheryl & Fromm, Harold|title=The ecocriticism reader: landmarks in literary ecology|publisher=University of Georgia Press|year=1998|isbn=978-0-8203-1781-6|page=305|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eJj4RlFKWCoC&pg=PA305}} Abbey's second son Aaron was born in 1959, in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]].{{Cite book|editor=Peterson, David|title=Postcards from Ed: dispatches and salvos from an American iconoclast|publisher=Milkweed Editions|year=2006|isbn=978-1-57131-284-6|page=277|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xb1lAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA277}} In the 1960s Abbey worked as a seasonal park ranger at [[Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument]], on the border of Arizona and Mexico. {{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} In 1961, the movie version of his second novel, ''[[The Brave Cowboy]],'' with screenplay by [[Dalton Trumbo]], was being shot on location in New Mexico by [[Kirk Douglas]] who had purchased the novel's screen rights and was producing and starring in the film, released in 1962 as ''[[Lonely Are the Brave]]''. Douglas once said that when Abbey visited the film set, he looked and talked so much like Douglas' friend [[Gary Cooper]] that Douglas was disconcerted. Nonetheless, over 25 years later when Abbey died, Douglas wrote that he had "never met" Abbey.{{cite news|last=Cox|first=Alex|title=The fretful Birth of the New Western|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/29/movies/kirk-douglass-film-lonely-are-the-brave.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=29 July 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=29 July 2012}} In 1981, Abbey's third novel, ''[[Fire on the Mountain (Abbey novel)|Fire on the Mountain]],'' was also adapted into a TV movie by the same title. On October 16, 1965, Abbey married Judy Pepper, who accompanied him as a seasonal park ranger in the [[Florida]] [[Everglades]] and then as a fire lookout in [[Lassen Volcanic National Park]].{{cite book|author=Loeffler, Jack|title=Adventures with Ed: A Portrait of Abbey|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-8263-2388-0|edition=Paper|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=woIQqklgU58C&pg=PA86}}{{RP|86-87}} Judy was separated from Abbey for extended periods of time while she attended the [[University of Arizona]] to earn her master's degree. During this time, Abbey had relations with other women—something that Judy gradually became aware of, causing their marriage to suffer.{{RP|92}} On August 8, 1968 Pepper gave birth to a daughter, Susannah "Susie" Mildred Abbey. Ed purchased the family a home in [[Sabino Canyon]], outside of [[Tucson]].{{RP|94}} Judy died of [[leukemia]] on July 11, 1970, an event that crushed Abbey, causing him to go into "bouts of depression and loneliness" for years. It was to Judy that he dedicated his book ''[[Black Sun (Abbey novel)|Black Sun]]''. However, the book was not an autobiographical novel about his relationship with Judy. Rather, it was a story about a woman with whom Abbey had an affair in 1963. Abbey finished the first draft of ''Black Sun'' in 1968, two years before Judy died, and it was "a bone of contention in their marriage."{{cite book|author=Pozza, David M.|title=Bedrock and Paradox; The Literary Landscape of Edward Abbey|publisher=Peter Lang Publishing|year=2006|isbn=0820463302|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ng_aL0prm9cC&pg=PA72}}{{RP|72–73}}{{RP|155}} ''Desert Solitaire'', Abbey's fourth book and first non-fiction work, was published in 1968. In it, he describes his stay in the canyonlands of southeastern Utah from 1956-1957.{{RP|13}} ''Desert Solitaire'' is regarded as one of the finest [[Nature Writing|nature narratives]] in American literature, and has been compared to [[Aldo Leopold]]'s ''[[A Sand County Almanac]]''{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} and Thoreau's ''[[Walden]]''.{{cite book|author=Olson, Ted|chapter="In Search of a More Human Nature": Wendell Berry's Revision of Thoreau's Experiment|editor=Schneider, Richard J.|title=Thoreau's sense of place: essays in American environmental writing|publisher=University of Iowa Press|year=2000|isbn=978-0-87745-708-4|page=63|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MQ7tX6h6SwAC&pg=PA63}} In it, Abbey vividly describes the physical landscapes of southern Utah and delights in his isolation as a back country park ranger, recounting adventures in the nearby canyon country and mountains. He also attacks what he terms the "industrial tourism" and resulting development in the national parks ("national parking lots"), rails against the [[Glen Canyon Dam]], and comments on various other subjects. {{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} In 1973, Abbey married his fourth wife Renee Downing. However, Abbey was always gone so they divorced after four years of marriage.Scheese, Donald. "Abbey, Edward." Encyclopedia of American Environmental History. Ed. Kathleen A. Brosnan. Vol. 1. New York: Facts on File, 2011. 75-76. Gale Virtual Reference Library. Web. 3 June 2013. ==Later life== Abbey met his fifth and final wife, Clarke Cartwright, in 1978,{{RP|68}} and married her in 1982.{{Cite book|editor=Oakes, Elizabeth H.|chapter=Abbey, Edward|title=American Authors|publisher=Infobase Publishing|year=2004|isbn=978-0-8160-5158-8|page=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6Lb0zPJcYOwC&pg=PA2}} Together they had two children, Rebecca Claire Abbey and Benjamin C. Abbey.[http://www.abbeyweb.net/bio/genealogy.html "Genealogy data"], ''AbbeyWeb'' In 1984, Abbey went back to the University of Arizona to teach courses in creative writing and hospitality management. During this time, he continued working on his book ''[[The Fool's Progress|Fool's Progress]]''.{{RP|180}} In July 1987, Abbey went to the Earth First! Rendezvous at the North Rim of the Grand Canyon. While there, he was involved in a heated debate with an [[anarchist communist]] group known as Alien Nation, over his stated view that America should be closed to all immigration.{{cite book|author=Lee, Martha Frances|title=Earth first! Environmental Apocalypse|publisher=Syracuse University Press|year=1995|edition=Paper|isbn=978-0-8156-0365-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hJLLqUnwSNMC&pg=PA105}}{{RP|105-107}} Abbey devoted an entire chapter in his book ''[[Hayduke Lives]]'' to the events that took place at the Rendezvous.{{RP|181}} In autumn of 1987, the ''[[Utne Reader]]'' published a letter by [[Murray Bookchin]] which claimed that Abbey, [[Garrett Hardin]], and the members of Earth First! were [[racists]] and [[eco-terrorists]]. Abbey was extremely offended and demanded a public apology, stating that he was neither racist nor a supporter of terrorism. All three of those Bookchin labelled "racist" opposed [[illegal immigration into the United States]], contending that population growth would cause further harm to the environment. Regarding the accusation of "eco-terrorism", Abbey responded that the tactics he supported were trying to defend against the terrorism he felt was committed by government and industry against living beings and the environment.{{RP|260}} ==Death and burial== {{quote box |quote=One final paragraph of advice: [...] It is not enough to fight for the land; it is even more important to enjoy it. While you can. While it's still here. So get out there and hunt and fish and mess around with your friends, ramble out yonder and explore the forests, climb the mountains, bag the peaks, run the rivers, breathe deep of that yet sweet and lucid air, sit quietly for a while and contemplate the precious stillness, the lovely, mysterious, and awesome space. Enjoy yourselves, keep your brain in your head and your head firmly attached to the body, the body active and alive, and I promise you this much; I promise you this one sweet victory over our enemies, over those desk-bound men and women with their hearts in a safe deposit box, and their eyes hypnotized by desk calculators. I promise you this; You will outlive the bastards. :~ Edward Abbey From a speech to environmentalists in [[Missoula, Montana]] and in Colorado, which was published in ''High Country News,'' (24 September 1976), under the title "Joy, Shipmates, Joy!", as quoted in ''Saving Nature's Legacy: Protecting and Restoring Biodiversity'' (1994) by Reed F. Noss, Allen Y. Cooperrider, and Rodger Schlickeisen, p. 338. {{ISBN|1-55963-248-8}} |width=40% }} Abbey died on March 14, 1989,{{cite book|author=Trimble, Stephen|chapter=Epilogue: Remembering Edward Abbey|title=Words from the land: encounters with natural history writing|publisher=University of Nevada Press|year=1995|isbn=978-0-87417-264-5|page=390|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v9lS0g1VA94C&pg=PA390}} aged 62, in his home in [[Tucson, Arizona]]. His death was due to complications from surgery; he suffered four days of esophageal hemorrhaging, due to [[esophageal varices]], which is a recurrent problem with one group of veins.{{RP|4}} Showing his sense of humor, he left a message for anyone who asked about his final words: "No comment." Abbey also left instructions on what to do with his remains: Abbey wanted his body transported in the bed of a pickup truck and wished to be buried as soon as possible. He did not want to be embalmed or placed in a [[coffin]]. Instead, he preferred to be placed inside of an old sleeping bag and requested that his friends disregard all state laws concerning burial. "I want my body to help fertilize the growth of a cactus or cliff rose or sagebrush or tree," said the message. For his funeral, Abbey stated, "No formal speeches desired, though the deceased will not interfere if someone feels the urge. But keep it all simple and brief." He requested gunfire and bagpipe music, a cheerful and raucous wake, "[a]nd a flood of beer and booze! Lots of singing, dancing, talking, hollering, laughing, and lovemaking."{{RP|4}}[[David Quammen|Quammen, David]], "Bagpipes for Ed", ''[[Outside (magazine)|Outside]]'', April 1989 A 2003 [[Outside (magazine)|Outside]]' article described how his friends honored his request: {{quote|The last time Ed smiled was when I told him where he was going to be buried," says [[Doug Peacock]], an environmental crusader in Edward Abbey's inner circle. On March 14, 1989, the day Abbey died from esophageal bleeding at 62, Peacock, along with his friend Jack Loeffler, his father-in-law Tom Cartwright, and his brother-in-law Steve Prescott, wrapped Abbey's body in his blue sleeping bag, packed it with dry ice, and loaded Cactus Ed into Loeffler's Chevy pickup. After stopping at a liquor store in Tucson for five cases of beer, and some whiskey to pour on the grave, they drove off into the desert. The men searched for the right spot the entire next day and finally turned down a long rutted road, drove to the end, and began digging. That night they buried Ed and toasted the life of America's prickliest and most outspoken environmentalist.{{cite news|author=Daley, Jason|title=Forever Wild|work=Outside|date=September 30, 2003|url=http://www.outsideonline.com/outdoor-adventure/Forever-Wild.html}}}} Abbey's body was buried in the [[Cabeza Prieta Wilderness|Cabeza Prieta Desert]] in [[Pima County, Arizona]], where "you'll never find it." The friends carved a marker on a nearby stone, reading:{{Cite book|author=Kowalewski, Michael|chapter=Introduction|editor=Kowalewski, Michael|title=Reading the West: New Essays on the Literature of the American West|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1996|isbn=978-0-521-56559-2|page=16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LELEsaRoH9oC&pg=PA16}}{{Cite book|author=Peterson, David|title=The nearby faraway: a personal journey through the heart of the West|publisher=Big Earth Publishing|year=1997|isbn=978-1-55566-187-8|page=88|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f3xjF6YwjtYC&pg=PA88}}
EDWARD PAUL ABBEY 1927—1989 No Comment
In late March, about 200 friends of Abbey's gathered near the [[Saguaro National Monument]] near Tucson and held the wake he requested. A second, much larger wake was held in May, just outside his beloved [[Arches National Park]], with such notables as [[Terry Tempest Williams]] and [[Wendell Berry]] speaking.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} Abbey is survived by two daughters, Susannah and Rebecca, and three sons, Joshua, Aaron, and Benjamin.http://www.abbeyweb.net/bio/genealogy.html He also has a nephew, David Abbey. == Documentaries == * ''Wrenched'',{{cite web|url=http://www.wrenched-themovie.com|title=Home - Wrenched|publisher=whrneched-themovie.com}} by Jerome filmmaker ML Lincoln is a 2013 documentary film that picks up where Edward Abbey's iconic novel ''The Monkey Wrench Gang'' left off, chronicling Abbey's legacy of environmental civil disobedience. This was originally called "Lines Across The Sand".{{cite web |url=http://www.linesacrossthesand.com |title=Lines Across The Sand - HOME |date=19 November 2011 |publisher=linesacrossthesand.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119021313/http://www.linesacrossthesand.com/ |archivedate=November 19, 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Home {{!}} Wrenched|url=http://wrenched-themovie.com|website=Wrenched|accessdate=4 December 2014|date=2014}} * ''Edward Abbey: A Voice in the Wilderness'' is a 1993 PBS documentary by Eric Temple. * ''The Cracking of Glen Canyon Damn — with Edward Abbey and Earth First!''(1982){{cite web|url=http://www.sacredland.org/the-cracking-of-glen-canyon-damn-with-edward-abbey-and-earth-first/|title=Index of /the-cracking-of-glen-canyon-damn-with-edward-abbey-and-earth-first|publisher=sacredland.org}} captured the legendary first action of radical desert rats when they dropped a 300-foot long black plastic "crack" over the dam and called poetically for its demise. Produced by Toby McLeod, Glenn Switkes and Randy Hayes. ==Literature== Abbey's literary influences included [[Aldo Leopold]], [[Henry David Thoreau]], [[Gary Snyder]], [[Peter Kropotkin]], and [[A. B. Guthrie, Jr.]].{{RP|221-222}}{{cite book|author=McClintock, James I.|title=Nature's kindred spirits: Aldo Leopold, Joseph Wood Krutch, Edward Abbey, Annie Dillard, and Gary Snyder|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|year=1994|isbn=978-0-299-14174-5|page=17|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tqTNLkOsmxUC&pg=PA17}} Although often compared to authors like Thoreau or Aldo Leopold, Abbey did not wish to be known as a [[nature writer]], saying that he didn't understand "why so many want to read about the world out-of-doors, when it's more interesting simply to go for a walk into the heart of it."{{cite book|author=McClintock, James I.|chapter=Edward Abbey: "An Earthiest"|title=Nature's kindred spirits: Aldo Leopold, Joseph Wood Krutch, Edward Abbey, Annie Dillard, and Gary Snyder|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|year=1994|isbn=978-0-299-14174-5|pages=67–68|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tqTNLkOsmxUC&pg=PA67}} The theme that most interested Abbey was that of the struggle for personal liberty against the totalitarian techno-industrial state, with wilderness being the backdrop in which this struggle took place.{{cite book|author=Payne, Daniel G.|chapter=Monkeywrenching, Environmental Extremism, and the Problematical Edward Abbey|title=Voices in the wilderness: American nature writing and environmental politics|publisher=UPNE|year=1996|isbn=978-0-87451-752-1|pages=156–157|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-NV2Ol3NfXMC&pg=PA156}} Most of Abbey's writing criticizes the park services and American society for its reliance on motor vehicles and technology. He wanted to preserve the wilderness as a refuge for humans and believed that modernization was making us forget what was truly important in life. Regarding his writing style, Abbey states: "I write in a deliberately provocative and outrageous manner because I like to startle people. I hope to wake up people. I have no desire to simply soothe or please. I would rather risk making people angry than putting them to sleep. And I try to write in a style that's entertaining as well as provocative. It's hard for me to stay serious for more than half a page at a time."{{cite book|editor=Trimble, Stephen|chapter=Introduction|title=Words from the land: encounters with natural history writing|publisher=University of Nevada Press|year=1995|isbn=978-0-87417-264-5|pages=27|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v9lS0g1VA94C&pg=PA27}} Abbey felt that it was the duty of all authors to "speak the truth--especially unpopular truth. Especially truth that offends the powerful, the rich, the well-established, the traditional, the mythic".{{cite book|author=Moore, Brian L.|title=Ecology and literature: ecocentric personification from antiquity to the twenty-first century|publisher=Macmillan|year=2008|isbn=978-0-230-60669-2|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eG2jcnPbvKQC&pg=PA174}} Abbey's abrasiveness, opposition to [[anthropocentrism]], and outspoken writings made him the object of much controversy. [[Agrarianism|Agrarian]] author [[Wendell Berry]] claimed that Abbey was regularly criticized by mainstream environmental groups because Abbey often advocated controversial positions that were very different from those which environmentalists were commonly expected to hold.{{Cite book|author=Nelson, Barney|title=The wild and the domestic: animal representation, ecocriticism, and western American literature|publisher=University of Nevada Press|year=2000|isbn=978-0-87417-347-5|page=92|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=id1-9GF7mz0C&pg=PA92}} Abbey has also drawn criticism for what some regard as his [[racism|racist]] and [[sexism|sexist]] views.{{cite news|url=http://www.utne.com/environment/1751.aspx#axzz328DY4CGi|title=Was Edward Abbey Racist and Sexist?|last=Goetzman|first=Keith|work=Utne Reader|date=July 30, 2009|accessdate=May 19, 2014}} In an essay called "Immigration and Liberal Taboos", collected in his 1988 book ''One Life at a Time, Please'', Abbey expressed his [[opposition to immigration]] ("legal or illegal, from any source") into the United States: "(I)t occurs to some of us that perhaps ever-continuing industrial and population growth is ''not'' the true road to human happiness, that simple gross quantitative increase of this kind creates only more pain, dislocation, confusion and misery. In which case it might be wise for us as American citizens to consider calling a halt to the mass influx of even more millions of hungry, ignorant, unskilled, and culturally-morally-generically impoverished people. At least until we have brought our own affairs into order. Especially when these uninvited millions bring with them an alien mode of life which—let us be honest about this—is not appealing to the majority of Americans. Why not? Because we prefer democratic government, for one thing; because we still hope for an open, spacious, uncrowded, and beautiful—yes, beautiful!—society, for another. The alternative, in the squalor, cruelty, and corruption of Latin America, is plain for all to see."{{cite book | last=Abbey | first=Edward | title=One Life at a Time, Please | location=New York | publisher=Henry Holt and Company | page=43 | date=1988 | isbn=0-805-00602-8}} It is often stated that Abbey's works played a significant role in precipitating the creation of [[Earth First!]].{{cite book|author=Taylor, Bron|chapter=Resacralizing Earth: Pagan Environmentalism and the Restoration of Turtle Island|editors=Chidester, David & Linenthal, Edward Tabor|title=American sacred space|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=1995|isbn=978-0-253-21006-7|page=105|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-C9pugPeqhMC&pg=PA105}} ''The Monkey Wrench Gang'' inspired environmentalists frustrated with mainstream environmentalist groups and what they saw as unacceptable compromises. [[Earth First!]] was formed as a result in 1980, advocating eco-sabotage or "[[monkeywrenching]]." Although Abbey never officially joined the group, he became associated with many of its members, and occasionally wrote for the organization{{cite book|editor=Peterson, David|title=Postcards From Ed: Dispatches and Salvos from an American Iconoclast|year=2006|publisher=(publisher?)|page={{page needed|date=January 2011}}|url=}} ===Works=== ====Fiction==== * ''[[Jonathan Troy]]'' (1954) ({{ISBN|1-131-40684-2}}) * ''[[The Brave Cowboy]]'' (1956) ({{ISBN|0-8263-0448-6}}) * ''[[Fire on the Mountain (Abbey novel)|Fire on the Mountain]]'' (1962) ({{ISBN|0-8263-0457-5}}) * ''[[Black Sun (Edward Abbey novel)|Black Sun]]'' (1971) ({{ISBN|0-88496-167-2}}) * ''[[The Monkey Wrench Gang]]'' (1975) ({{ISBN|0-397-01084-2}}) * ''[[Good News (1980 novel)|Good News]]'' (1980) ({{ISBN|0-525-11583-8}}) * ''[[The Fool's Progress]]'' (1988) ({{ISBN|0-8050-0921-3}}) * ''[[Hayduke Lives]]'' (1990) ({{ISBN|0-316-00411-1}}) * ''Earth Apples: The Poetry of Edward Abbey'' (1994) ({{ISBN|0-312-11265-3}}) ====Non-fiction==== * ''[[Desert Solitaire]]: A Season in the Wilderness'' (1968) ({{ISBN|0-8165-1057-1}}) * ''Appalachian Wilderness'' (1970) * ''Slickrock'' (1971) ({{ISBN|0-87156-051-8}}) * ''Cactus Country'' The American Wilderness/Time-Life books (1973) * ''The Journey Home'' (1977) ({{ISBN|0-525-13753-X}}) * ''The Hidden Canyon'' (1977) * ''Abbey's Road'' (1979) ({{ISBN|0-525-05006-X}}) * ''Desert Images'' (1979) * ''[[Down the River]] (with Henry Thoreau & Other Friends)'' (1982) ({{ISBN|0-525-09524-1}}) * ''In Praise of Mountain Lions'' (1984) * ''Beyond the Wall'' (1984) ({{ISBN|0-03-069299-7}}) * ''One Life at a Time, Please'' (1988) ({{ISBN|0-8050-0602-8}}) * ''A Voice Crying in the Wilderness: Notes from a Secret Journal'' (1989) * ''Confessions of a Barbarian: Selections from the Journals of Edward Abbey, 1951–1989'' (1994) ({{ISBN|0-316-00415-4}}) ====Letters==== * ''[http://www.orionmagazine.org/index.php/articles/article/173/ Cactus Chronicles]'' published by ''Orion Magazine'', Jul–Aug 2006 (no longer active,) * ''Postcards from Ed (book)|Postcards from Ed: Dispatches and Salvos from an American Iconoclast'' (2006) ({{ISBN|1-57131-284-6}}) ====Anthologies==== * ''Slumgullion Stew: An Edward Abbey Reader'' (1984) * ''The Best of Edward Abbey'' (1984) * ''The Serpents of Paradise: A Reader'' (1995) ==See also== * ''[[Ecodefense|Ecodefense: A Field Guide to Monkeywrenching]]'' (foreword written by Edward Abbey) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|author=Prentiss, Sean|title=Finding Abbey: The Search for Edward Abbey And His Hidden Desert Grave|year=2015|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|ISBN=978-0-8263-5591-1}} * {{cite book|author=Abbey, Edward|chapter=Earth First! and ''The Monkeywrench Gang''|editor=Keller, David R.|title=Environmental Ethics: The Big Questions|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=2010|isbn=978-1-4051-7639-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YKQmqFfrT5EC&pg=PA327}} * {{cite book|author=Cahalan, James M.|title=Edward Abbey: A Life|publisher=University of Arizona Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-8165-2267-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-q4EAAAACAAJ}} * {{cite book|author=Foreman, Dave|title=[[Confessions of an Eco-Warrior]]|publisher=Crown Publishing|year=1992|ISBN=0-517-88058-X}} * {{cite book|author=Gessner, David|title=All the Wild That Remains: Edward Abbey, Wallace Stegner, and the American West|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|year=2015|isbn=978-0-393-08999-8}} * {{cite book|author=Knott, John Ray|chapter=Edward Abbey and the Romance of the Wilderness|title=Imagining wild America|publisher=University of Michigan|year=2002|isbn=978-0-472-06806-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IwI87yH-IFgC&pg=PA111}} * {{cite book|author=Lane, Belden C.|chapter=Mythic Landscapes: The Desert Imagination of Edward Abbey|title=Landscapes of the sacred: geography and narrative in American spirituality|publisher=JHU Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-8018-6838-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pvsBqbeG-4gC&pg=PA124}} * {{cite book|author=Meyer, Kurt A.|title=Edward Abbey: freedom fighter, freedom writer|publisher=University of Wyoming Press|year=1987|isbn=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cyUrOAAACAAJ}} * {{cite book|editor=Quigley, Peter|title=Coyote in the maze: tracking Edward Abbey in a world of words|publisher=University of Utah Press|year=1998|isbn=978-0-87480-563-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LTpaAAAAMAAJ}} * {{cite book|author=Ronald, Ann|chapter=The Nevada Scene Through Edward Abbey's Eyes|title=Reader of the purple sage: essays on Western writers and environmental literature|publisher=University of Nevada Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-87417-524-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c_l931iX_IcC&pg=PA70}} * {{cite book|author=Slovic, Scott|chapter="Rudolf the red knows rain, dear": The Aestheticism of Edward Abbey|title=Seeking awareness in American nature writing: Henry Thoreau, Annie Dillard, Edward Abbey, Wendell Berry, Barry Lopez|publisher=University of Utah Press|year=1992|isbn=978-0-87480-362-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9tyhPucLt2sC&pg=PA93}} * {{cite book|author=Wild, Peter|authorlink=Peter Wild|chapter=Edward Abbey: Ned Ludd Arrives on the Desert|title=The opal desert: explorations of fantasy and reality in the American Southwest|publisher=University of Texas Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0-292-79129-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IKaje8HQNtwC&pg=PA146}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.abbeyweb.net/ AbbeyWeb] - information about Edward Abbey and his books *[https://westernamericanliterature.wordpress.com/edward-abbey/ Western American Literature: Edward Abbey] * {{iblist name|id=541|name=Edward Abbey}} * {{ibdof name|id=495|name=Edward Abbey}} * {{isfdb name|id=Edward_Abbey|name=Edward Abbey}} * {{IMDb name|0007872}} * {{worldcat id|id=lccn-n78-93802}} * {{NYTtopic|people/a/edward_abbey}} *[http://archiveswest.orbiscascade.org/ark:/80444/xv00601/op=fstyle.aspx?t=k&q=Edward+Abbey Edward Abbey papers, 1954-1980] *[http://archiveswest.orbiscascade.org/ark:/80444/xv41323/op=fstyle.aspx?t=k&q=Edward+Abbey Edward Abbey audio collection, 1981-1989] *[[iarchive:EdwardAbbey|FBI files on Edward Abbey]] {{Edward revision.text:
'''Ferroelectret'''s also known as '''piezoelectret'''s, are thin films of [[polymer foam]]s, exhibiting [[piezoelectric]] and [[pyroelectric]] properties after electric charging. Ferroelectret foams usually consist of a cellular polymer structure filled with air. Polymer-air composites are elastically soft due to their high air content as well as due to the size and shape of the polymer walls. Their elastically soft composite structure is one essential key for the working principle of ferroelectrets, besides the permanent trapping of electric charges inside the polymer voids. The elastic properties allow large deformations of the electrically charged voids. However, the composite structure can also possibly limit the stability and consequently the range of applications.<ref>A. Mellinger, M. Wegener, W. Wirges, R. Mallepally and R. Gerhard-Multhaupt:''Thermal and Temporal Stability of Ferroelectret Films Made from Cellular Polypropylene/Air Composites'', ''Ferroelectrics'', Volume 331, Number 1, pp. 189–199(11), 2006.</ref>
==How it works==
The most common effect related to ferroelectrets is the direct and inverse piezoelectricity, but in these materials, the effect occurs in a way different from the respective effect in [[ferroelectric polymers]]. In ferroelectric polymers, a stress in the 3-direction mainly decreases the distance between the molecular chains, due to the relatively weak van der Waals and electrostatic interactions between chains in comparison to the strong covalent bonds within the chain. The thickness decrease thus results in an increase of the dipole density and thus in an increase of the charges on the electrodes, yielding a negative d33 coefficient from dipole-density (or secondary) piezoelectricity. In cellular polymers (ferroelectrets), stress in the 3-direction also decreases the thickness of the sample. The thickness decrease occurs dominantly across the voids, the macroscopic dipole moments decrease, and so do the electrode charges, yielding a positive d33 (intrinsic or direct (quasi-)piezoelectricity).<ref>M. Lindner, H. Hoislbauer, R. Schwödiauer, S. Bauer-Gogonea and S. Bauer:''Charged Cellular Polymers with ‘‘Ferroelectretic’’Behavior'', ''IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation'', Volume 11, Number 2, pp. 255–263; April 2004.</ref><ref>J. Hillenbrand and G.M. Sessler, ''High-sensitivity piezoelectric microphones based on stacked cellular polymer films (L)'', J. Acoust. Soc. Am. 116 (6), December 2004.</ref>
==New features==
In recent years, alternatives to the cellular-foam ferroelectrets were developed. In the new polymer systems, the required cavities are formed by means of e.g. stamps, templates, laser cutting, etc. Thermo-forming of layer systems from electret films led to thermally more stable ferroelectrets.<ref>R.A.C. Altafim, H.C. Basso, R.A.P. Altafim, L. Lima, C.V. de Aquino, L.G. Neto, R. Gerhard-Multhaupt: ''Piezoelectrets from thermo-formed bubble structures of fluoropolymer-electret films'', ''IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation'', Vol. 13, pages 979-985, 2006.</ref><ref>X. Zhang, J. Hillenbrand and G.M. Sessler: ''Ferroelectrets with improved thermal stability made from fused fluorocarbon layers'', ''Journal of Applied Physics'', Vol. 101, 2007.</ref><ref>R.A.P. Altafim, X. Qiu, W. Wirges, R. Gerhard, R.A.C. Altafim, H.C. Basso, W. Jenninger and J. Wagner:''Template-based fluoroethylenepropylene piezoelectrets with tubular channels for transducer applications'', ''Journal of Applied Physics'', Vol. 106, 2009.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * [[Reimund Gerhard|R. Gerhard-Multhaupt]], ''Less Can Be More - Holes in Polymers lead to a new paradigm of piezoelectric materials for electret transducers'', ''IEEE Transactions on Dielectric and Electrical Insulation'', Vol. 9, No. 5, pages 850-859, 2002. * S. Bauer, R. Gerhard-Multhaupt, and [[Gerhard M. Sessler|G. M. Sessler]], ''Ferroelectrets: Soft Electroactive Foams for Transducers'', ''Physics Today'', Vol. 57, pages 37–43, February 2004. * M. Wegener and S. Bauer, ''Microstorms in Cellular Polymers: A route to soft piezoelectric transducer materials with engineered macroscopic dipoles'', ''ChemPhysChem'', Vol. 6, pages 1014-1025, 2005. * S. Bauer, ''Piezo-, pyro- and ferro-electrets: Soft transducer materials for electromechanical energy conversion'', ''IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation'', Vol. 13, No. 5, pages 953–962, 2006.

{{short description|Type of intense dust storm}} [[File:Haboob Ransom Canyon Texas 2009.jpg|thumb|right|425px|A haboob moves across the [[Llano Estacado]] toward [[Yellow House Canyon]], near the residential community of [[Ransom Canyon, Texas]] (18 June 2009)]]
A '''haboob''' ({{lang-ar|هَبوب|lit=blasting/drifting|translit=habūb}}) is a type of intense [[dust storm]] carried on an atmospheric [[gravity current]], also known as a [[weather front]]. Haboobs occur regularly in [[arid|dry land area]] regions throughout the world.
== Description ==
During thunderstorm formation, winds move in a direction opposite to the storm's travel, and they move from all directions into the thunderstorm. When the storm collapses and begins to release precipitation, wind directions reverse, gusting outward from the storm and generally gusting the strongest in the direction of the storm's travel.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/qj.49706327111|title=Haboobs and instability in the sudan|year=1937|last1=Farquharson|first1=J. S.|journal=Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society|volume=63|issue=271|pages=393–414|bibcode = 1937QJRMS..63..393F }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1002/j.1477-8696.1971.tb07402.x|title=Haboob Structure at Khartoum|year=1971|last1=Lawson|first1=T. J.|journal=Weather|volume=26|issue=3|pages=105–112|bibcode = 1971Wthr...26..105L }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1002/j.1477-8696.1985.tb06877.x|title=A Gravity-Wave Haboob?|year=1985|last1=Membery|first1=D. A.|journal=Weather|volume=40|issue=7|pages=214–221|bibcode = 1985Wthr...40..214M }}</ref>
When this downdraft of cold air, or [[downburst]], reaches the ground, it blows dry, loose silt and clay (collectively, dust) up from the desert, creating a wall of sediment that precedes the storm cloud. This wall of dust can be up to {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide and several kilometers in elevation. At their strongest, haboob winds often travel at {{convert|35|–|100|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}, and they may approach with little or no warning. Often rain does not appear at ground level as it evaporates in the hot, dry air (a phenomenon known as [[virga]]). The evaporation cools the rushing air even further and accelerates it. Occasionally, when the rain does persist, it can contain a considerable quantity of dust. Severe cases are called ''mud storms''. Eye and respiratory system protection is advisable for anyone who must be outside during a haboob. Moving to shelter is highly advised during a strong event.
== Occurrence ==
=== Middle East ===
Haboobs have been observed in the [[Sahara desert]] (typically [[Sudan]], where they were named and described), as well as across the [[Arabian Peninsula]], throughout [[Kuwait]], and in the most arid regions of [[Iraq]].<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1002/qj.49705121305|title=Haboobs|year=1925|last1=Sutton|first1=L. J.|journal=Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society|volume=51|issue=213|pages=25–30|bibcode = 1925QJRMS..51...25S }}</ref> Haboob [[wind]]s in the Arabian Peninsula, Iraq, Kuwait are frequently created by the collapse of a [[thunderstorm]].
=== North Africa ===
African haboobs result from the northward summer shift of the inter-tropical front into [[North Africa]], bringing moisture from the [[Gulf of Guinea]].
=== Australia ===
Haboobs in Australia may be frequently associated with [[cold front]]s. The deserts of [[Central Australia]], especially near [[Alice Springs]], are particularly prone to haboobs, with sand and debris reaching several kilometers into the sky and leaving up to {{convert|30|cm|ft|0}} of sand in the haboob's path.
=== North America === {{seealso|North American Monsoon}} As with haboobs in the Middle East, haboob occurrences in North America are often created by the collapse of a thunderstorm. This is a local or mesoscale event, and at times of extreme drought they can originate in agricultural regions. Some of the most famous dust storms of the Dust Bowl and similar conditions later were in fact synoptic scale events typically generated by a strong cold frontal passage, with 14 April 1935, 9–11 May 1934, 19 February 1954, and 11 November 1911 being particularly vivid examples.
The arid and semiarid regions of [[North America]]—in fact, any dry region—may experience haboobs. In North America, the most common terms for these events are either [[dust storm]] or sandstorm. In the U.S., they frequently occur in the deserts of [[Arizona]], including around the cities of [[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma]] and [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]];<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1175/1520-0477(1972)053<0930:AAH>2.0.CO;2|year=1972|volume=53|issue=10|pages=930–935|title=An American Haboob|last1=Idso|first1=S. B.|last2=Ingram|first2=R. S.|last3=Pritchard|first3=J. M.|journal=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|bibcode = 1972BAMS...53..930I }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1002/j.1477-8696.1973.tb02253.x|title=Haboobs in Arizona|year=1973|last1=Idso|first1=Carolyn W.|journal=Weather|volume=28|issue=4|pages=154–155|bibcode = 1973Wthr...28..154I }}</ref> in [[New Mexico]], including [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]]; in eastern [[California]], and in [[Texas]].<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0169-8095(01)00092-8|title=Sedimentary characteristics of a haboob dust storm|year=2002|last1=Chen|first1=W.|last2=Fryrear|first2=D. W.|journal=Atmospheric Research|volume=61|issue=1|pages=75–85|bibcode = 2002AtmRe..61...75C }}</ref> They also sometimes occur in the [[Columbia Plateau (ecoregion)|Columbia Basin]], of [[Eastern Washington|Eastern]] [[Washington (State)|Washington]], almost always leading to an impact with the city of [[Spokane]]. If the storms are strong enough, they can reach as far east as [[Post Falls]] and [[Moscow, Idaho|Moscow]], in [[North Idaho|North]] [[Idaho]].
=== Mars === [[Climate of Mars#Effect of dust storms|Global dust storms on Mars]] have been compared to haboobs on Earth.<ref>Boyle, R. (2017). "Everything About Mars Is The Worst." FiveThirtyEight. Retrieved 9 March 2017, from https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/everything-about-mars-is-the-worst/</ref>
== Gallery ==
<gallery class="center" mode="packed"> File:United Nations Dash 8 Haboob Sudan UA-320-1.jpg|A haboob closes in on [[Nyala Airport]], Sudan in 2012 File:DustStormInSpearmanTexas19350414.jpg|[[Dust Bowl]]-era haboob approaching [[Spearman, Texas]], US in 1935 File:Haboob2.jpg|Haboob blowing into [[Ahwatukee, Phoenix, Arizona]], US in 2003 File:Sandstorm.jpg|A massive haboob is close to enveloping [[Al Asad Airbase]], [[Iraq]], just before nightfall in 2005 File:Haboob, Taji, Iraq, 2006.JPG|A haboob approaches [[Taji, Iraq]], in 2006 </gallery>

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/203.87.156.129|203.87.156.129]] ([[User talk:203.87.156.129|talk]]) to last revision by Staszek Lem. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2010}} People often see '''hidden faces''' in things. Depending on the circumstances, this is referred to as [[pareidolia]], the perception or recognition of a specific pattern or form in something essentially different. It is thus also a kind of [[optical illusion]]. When an artist notices that two different things have a similar appearance, and draws or paints a picture making this similarity evident he makes images with double meanings. Many of these images are hidden faces or hidden skulls.
These illusionistic pictures present the viewer with a mental choice of two interpretations: head or landscape, head or objects, head or architecture, etc. Both of them are valid, but the viewer sees only one of them and very often he cannot see both interpretations simultaneously. [[File:NeptunesGrottoOrganPlayer.jpg|thumb|right|"The Organ Player" - Pareidolia phenomenon in [[Neptune's Grotto]], [[Sardinia]]]] ==Chance images== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width =
| image1 = Pareidolia 3.jpg | width1 = 146 | alt1 = | caption1 = Chance image: An alarm clock where a "sad face" could be perceived.
| image2 = Hidden face1.jpg | width2 = 136 | alt2 = | caption2 = Sometimes buildings provide shapes which can be interpreted as "faces". (In ''[[Mon Oncle]]'' the filmmaker [[Jaques Tati]] gave a house "rolling eyes" by letting two actors move behind the windows.) }} There are everyday examples of hidden faces, they are "chance images" including faces in the clouds, figures of the [[Rorschach Test]] and the [[Man in the Moon]]. [[Leonardo da Vinci]] wrote about them in his notebook: "If you look at walls that are stained or made of different kinds of stones you can think you see in them certain picturesque views of mountains, rivers, rocks, trees, plains, broad valleys, and hills of different shapes. You can also find in them battles and rapidly moving figures, strange faces and costumes, as well as an infinite number of things." [[Francois and Jean Robert]] collected and published a lot of photos of "chance faces".{{clear}}
==Hidden faces created by artists== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width =
| image1 = Gheerhaets Allegory iconoclasm.jpg | width1 = 146 | alt1 = | caption1 = [[Marcus Gheeraerts the Elder]]: ''Allegory of Iconoclasts'', (c. 1567)<ref name="KnightLetter99">{{cite journal | author=Kluge, Goetz | title=Nose Is a Nose Is a Nose | url=http://snrk.de/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Nose_is_a_Nose_is_a_Nose.pdf | journal=Knight Letter | date=December 2017 | series=Number 99 | page= 30 | ISSN=0193-886X}}</ref>
| image2 = SnarkTheVanishing.jpg | width2 = 136 | alt2 = | caption2 = Hidden Face of the "Baker" in an illustration by [[Henry Holiday]] to [[Lewis Carroll]]'s ''[[The Hunting of the Snark]]'' (1876)<ref name="KnightLetter99" /> }} The Mannerist master at the 16th-century imperial Habsburg courts of Vienna and Prague, [[Giuseppe Arcimboldo]] of [[Milan]] was probably the best known artist for creating extraordinary hidden faces. He arranged flowers, vegetables, fruits, shells, scallops and other animals, books and different things on the canvas in such a way that the whole collection of objects formed a portrait. His series of The Four Seasons seems to be the first use of this approach and technique. Arcimboldo's composite heads were celebrated and imitated by his contemporaries but they were relatively forgotten until participants in the twentieth-century art movements rediscovered them, bringing them to the attention of art historians. He is considered as forerunner of [[Dada]] and [[Surrealism]].{{cn|date=October 2018}}
Some other famous [[Renaissance]] and [[Baroque]] artists created hidden faces:{{cn|date=October 2018}} *[[Leonardo da Vinci]] *[[Albrecht Dürer]] *[[Tobias Stimmer]] *[[Hans Holbein the Younger]] *[[Matthäus Merian]] *[[Anna Maria Sibylla Merian]] *[[Marcus Gheeraerts the Elder]] *[[Wenzel Hollar]] *[[Josse de Momper]]
[[Salvador Dalí]] was fascinated by the technique of Arcimboldo and his paranoia-critical method was influenced by the [[Mannerist]] painter. For Dalí the Arcimboldo effect was form of self concealment as well as this exhibitionist painter seemed, all throughout his life of constant posturing, to hide his [[real self]] behind the gaudy externals of his behaviour. Larvatus prodeo, "I wear a mask," he could have said with Descartes and he used this quotation from the French philosopher for the epigraph of his novel ''Hidden Faces''.{{cn|date=October 2018}} Probably his most famous "hidden face" is [[Voltaire]] in his oil painting: "Slave Market with the Disappearing Bust of Voltaire". Other [[Surrealist]] painters rediscovered the technique of hidden faces in the first part of 20th century: *[[Max Ernst]]{{cn|date=October 2018}} *[[René Magritte]]{{cn|date=October 2018}}
[[Istvan Orosz]] tries to combine the technique of [[anamorphosis]] with the hidden faces. Anamorphosis is used for those works of art that were made as distorted and unrecognizable through clever geometrical constructions. But when viewed from a certain point, or through a reflecting object placed upon it, the hidden image appears in its true shape, that is, it goes through retransformation. Orosz made experiments with anamorphoses not only in resurrecting the old technique but to improve and develop it. Instead of having a meaningless distorted image, his intent is to bring sense to the basic anamorphic picture, giving it meaning in itself with its second reading being revealed by viewing it from a different viewpoint such as looking at it through a special mirror.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gallery-diabolus.com/gallery/upload/utisz/Verne00.jpg |title=Anamorphosis with double meanings: landscape and portrait of Jules Verne in the mirror cylinder |publisher=gallery-diabolus.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927070312/http://www.gallery-diabolus.com/gallery/upload/utisz/Verne00.jpg |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> The ambiguous layers coming up by this approach make use of the connection or contrast of the two images within the same picture being independent from each other.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallery-diabolus.com/gallery/upload/utisz/shakespeareszinhaz.jpg |title=Anamorphosis with double meanings: a theatre and portrait of William Shakespeare. (View from a narrow angle!) |publisher=gallery-diabolus.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927070135/http://www.gallery-diabolus.com/gallery/upload/utisz/shakespeareszinhaz.jpg |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
There are many other contemporary works using hidden faces: *[[Shigeo Fukuda]]{{cn|date=October 2018}} *[[Octavio Ocampo]]{{cn|date=October 2018}} *[[Sandro del Prete]]{{cn|date=October 2018}} {{clear}}
<gallery> Vertumnus årstidernas gud målad av Giuseppe Arcimboldo 1591 - Skoklosters slott - 91503.tiff|[[Giuseppe Arcimboldo]]: [[Vertumnus (painting)|''Vertumnus'']], a portrait of [[Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor|Rudolf II]] (1590 -1591) Giuseppe Arcimboldo, Reversible Head with Basket of Fruit, c. 1590, oil on panel.jpg|Reversible Head with Basket of Fruit, oil on panel painting by Giuseppe Arcimboldo Bibliotekarien konserverad - Skoklosters slott - 97136.tif|Giuseppe Arcimboldo: ''[[The Librarian (painting)|The Librarian]]'' Stimmer.jpg|[[Tobias Stimmer]]: Hidden Portrait of the Pope (1577) Allisvanity.jpg|"''All is Vanity''" by [[Charles Allan Gilbert|C. Allan Gilbert]]. Life, death, and meaning of existence are intertwined Wenceslas Hollar - Landscape shaped like a face (State 1).jpg|[[Wenzel Hollar]] (1607-1677): Landscape </gallery>
==See also== *[[Face perception]] *[[Anamorphosis]] *[[Giuseppe Arcimboldo]] *[[Salvador Dalí]] *[[Anna Maria Sibylla Merian]] *[[Istvan Orosz]] *[[Rubin vase]] *[[Utisz]] *[[Hide-and-Seek (painting)|''Hide-and-Seek'']], a painting by [[Pavel Tchelitchew]] *[[Optical illusions]]
==Literature== The pioneering study on the matter is an academic dissertation, unpublished to this day: Anita Joplin, ''The Anthropomorphic Landscape: A Study in 16th Century Imagery'' (unpublished thesis, Reed College), 1974.
===On anthropomorphic landscapes=== * Fernand Hallyn, "Le paysage anthropomorphe", Yves Giraud (ed.), ''Le Paysage à la Renaissance'', Fribourg: Editions universitaires de Fribourg, 1988, pp. 43 ss. * Michel Weemans & Jean-Hubert Martin (eds.), ''Le paysage anthropomorphe à la Renaissance'' (international conference proceedings, 2009), Paris: Réunion des musées nationaux, (awatiting publication). * Michel Weemans, "Herri met de Bles’s sleeping peddler: an exegetical and anthropomorphic landscape", ''The Art Bulletin'', Vol. 88, Iss. 3, pp. 459–481. * Andreas Hauser, « Andrea Mantegnas ‘Wolkenreiter’: Manifestationen von kunstloser Natur oder Ursprung von vexierbildhafter Kunst ? », Gerhart von Graevenitz, Stefan Rieger, Felix Thürlemann (eds.), ''Die Unvermeidlichkeit der Bilder'', Tübingen, 2001, pp. 147-172. * Omar Calabrese (2006): ''Artists' Self-Portraits'', {{ISBN|978-0-7892-0894-1}} (The book has a chapter on artists who hide self-portraits in their pictures: e.g. Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Rembrandt, van Gogh, Munch, Dalí, Albrecht Dürer, Velàzquez, Elisabeth Vigée-Lebrun, Ingres, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Gainsborough, Matisse, James Ensor, Egon Schiele, Frida Kahlo, Man Ray, Henry Moore, Robert Rauschenberg, Norman Rockwell, and Roy Lichtenstein.)
===On crypto-images more broadly=== * Walter Melion, Bret Rothstein, Michel Weemans (eds.), ''The Anthropomorphic Lens: Anthropomorphism, Microcosmism and Analogy in Early Modern Thought and Visual Arts'', Leiden: Brill, 2015. * Jean-Hubert Martin (ed.), ''Une image peut en cacher une autre - Arcimboldo, Dalí, Raetz'' (exhibition catalogue), Paris: Galeries nationales du Grand Palais, 2009. {{ISBN|978-2-7118-5586-5}} * Jean-Hubert Martin, Stephan Andreae (eds.), ''Das endlose Rätsel. Dalí und die Magier der Mehrdeutigkeit'' (exhibition catalogue, Düsseldorf, Museum Kunst Palast), Ostfildern-Ruit, 2003. * Dario Gamboni, ''Potential images: ambiguity and indeterminacy in modern art'', London: Reaktion, 2002. * Jean-Claude Lebensztejn, ''L'art de la tache: Introduction à la'' Nouvelle methode ''d'Alexander Cozens'', Paris: Éditions du Limon, 1990. * Jean-Didier Urbain, "La crypto-image ou le palimpseste iconique", ''Eidos'', 5, 1991, p. 1-16, et * Horst W. Janson, "The ‘Image made by Chance’ in Renaissance Thought", Millard Meiss (ed.), ''De Artibus opuscula XL. Essays in Honor of Erwin Panofsky'', New York, 1961, I, pp. 254– 266, II, pp. 87–88.
==Notes== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hidden Faces}} [[Category:Optical illusions]] [[Category:Optical phenomena]] [[Category:Artistic techniques]]

{{Infobox lake | name = Lake Meke
Meke Gölü | image = Lake Meke - Meke Gölü 07.JPG | caption = Lake Meke with [[volcanic cone]] inside | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Karapınar]], [[Konya Province]] | coords = {{coord|37|41|07|N|33|38|28|E|region:TR_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | lake_type = [[Crater lake]] | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = Turkey | length = {{convert|800|m|ft|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} | area = | depth = {{convert|12|m|ft|abbr=on}} | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = {{convert|981|m|ft|abbr=on}} | islands = | cities = | pushpin_map = Turkey | pushpin_label_position = right | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Lake Meke in Turkey. | embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Meke Maar | designation1_date = 21 July 2005 | designation1_number = 1618{{Cite web|title=Meke Maar|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/1618|accessdate=25 April 2018}}}} }} '''Lake Meke''' ({{lang-tr|Meke Gölü}}) is a [[crater lake]] composed of two nested lakes located in [[Konya Province]], central Turkey. It is a registered [[List of natural monuments of Turkey|natural monument of the country]] and a [[List of Ramsar sites in Turkey|Ramsar site]]. Lake Meke is located in [[Karapınar]] district of Konya Province. It is {{convert|9|km|mi|abbr=on}} away from Karapınar, and {{convert|2|km|mi|abbr=on}} south of the [[Konya]]-[[Adana]] highway {{TUR-D|330}} {{European route E|981}}. It was formed by the flooding of the [[Volcanic crater|crater]] of an [[extinct volcano]], which took shape about 4 million years ago when the volcano erupted.{{Citation needed|reason=Interesting formation; would be good to have citation|date=March 2017}} About 9,000 years ago, a second eruption formed another [[volcanic cone]] inside the lake with a [[maar]]. Lake Meke now consists of two lakes with various islets. It is {{convert|800|m|ft|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide with a depth of {{convert|12|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The inner lake inside the {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}}-high volcanic cone is {{convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep, and contains [[saline water]]. The volcanic cone island resisted erosion by the harsh weather conditions due to its massive material, and has retained its form for thousands of years. ==Protected areas== Lake Meke was declared a first grade [[protected area]] in 1989. It was registered as a natural monument in 1998. On June 21, 2005, the lake and its surrounding area was declared a [[Ramsar site]] because of its international importance for wildfowl. ==Declining water level== A scientist from [[Selçuk University]] in Konya stated in 2009 that the lake had nearly dried up. He stated that the reason behind this was the uncontrolled extraction of water for agricultural [[irrigation]] and [[overdrafting]]. In 2012, it was reported that the lake's capacity had decreased by about 60% within the last twenty years and that there was a risk that it would dry out completely. In many sections of the lake, the water was becoming increasingly saline and [[crystallization]] was occurring. A drought season in 2014 caused a lowering of the [[groundwater]] level which was responsible for the further drying out of the lake to an extent of almost 99%. The remaining water body was turned red by the large quantity of [[microorganism]]s present in the [[brackish water]]. Nearly a hundred species of bird which were previously seen at the lake, had by 2015 moved elsewhere. ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.turkiyesulakalanlari.com/meke-maari-konya/ |publisher=Türkiye Sulak Alanları |title=Meke Maarı – Konya |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-01-15 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.turkiyesulakalanlari.com/wp-content/uploads/Turkeys-Ramsar-Sites.pdf |publisher=Türkiye Sulak Alanları |title=Turkey’s Important Wetlands – Ramsar Sites |accessdate=2017-02-11 }} {{cite news |url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/dunyanin-nazar-boncugu-meke-golu--haritadan-silinme-noktasina-geldi-gundem-1141414/ |newspaper=[[Milliyet]] |title=Dünyanın nazar boncuğu Meke Gölü, This listing contains 454 genera, and is divided up into sub-taxa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/gnlist.pl?77 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-09-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924061158/http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/gnlist.pl?77 |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref>

page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on Rumex

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of Lepidoptera that feed on ''Rumex''}} Docks and sorrels ('''''[[Rumex]]''''' species) are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] [[species]], including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species which feed exclusively on ''Rumex''
* [[Nepticulidae]] **''[[Enteucha acetosae]]'' - feeds on [[sheep's sorrel]] (''[[Rumex acetosella|R. acetosella]]'') and [[common sorrel]] (''[[Rumex acetosa|R. acetosa]]'') * [[Coleophoridae]] **''[[Coleophora hydrolapathella]]'' - feeds on [[great water dock]] (''[[Rumex hydrolapathum|R. hydrolapathum]]'') * [[Gelechiidae]] **''[[Chionodes ochreostrigella]]''
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on ''Rumex'' and other plants
* [[Arctiidae]] **[[Buff ermine]] (''Spilosoma luteum'') * [[Gelechiidae]] **''[[Chionodes discoocellella]]'' * [[Geometridae]] **[[Blood-vein]] (''Timandra griseata'') **[[Common marbled carpet]] (''Chloroclysta truncata'') **[[Engrailed (moth)|Engrailed]] (''Ectropis crepuscularia'') **[[Gem (moth)|Gem]] (''Orthonama obstipata'' subfamily [[Larentiinae]]) **[[Lime-speck pug]] (''Eupithecia centaureata'') **[[Mottled beauty]] (''Alcis repandata'') * [[Gracillariidae]] **''[[Calybites phasianipennella]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=296 ''Calybites phasianipennella''|url=https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=4924|publisher=UK''moths''|accessdate=16 August 2013}}</ref> * [[Hepialidae]] **[[Ghost moth]] (''Hepialus humuli'') **[[Orange swift]] (''Triodia sylvina'') * [[Lymantriidae]] **[[Brown-tail]] (''Euproctis chrysorrhoea'') * [[Noctuidae]] **[[Angle shades]] (''Phlogophora meticulosa'') **[[Autumnal rustic]] (''Eugnorisma glareosa'') **[[Cabbage moth]] (''Mamestra brassicae'') **[[Double square-spot]] (''Xestia triangulum'') **[[Flame (moth)|Flame]] (''Axylia putris'') **[[Flame shoulder]] (''Ochropleura plecta'') **[[Grey chi]] (''Antitype chi'') **[[Heart and club]] (''Agrotis clavis'') **[[Heart and dart]] (''Agrotis exclamationis'') **[[Hebrew character]] (''Orthosia gothica'') **[[Ingrailed clay]] (''Diarsia mendica'') **[[Lesser broad-bordered yellow underwing]] (''Noctua janthina'') **[[Lesser yellow underwing]] (''Noctua comes'') **[[Mouse moth]] (''Amphipyra tragopoginis'') **[[Setaceous Hebrew character]] (''Xestia c-nigrum'') **[[Six-striped rustic]] (''Xestia sexstrigata'') **[[Turnip moth]] (''Agrotis segetum'') * [[Saturniidae]] **[[Emperor moth]] (''Pavonia pavonia'')
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Rumex&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Rumex''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 7 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Rumex]] [[Category:Rumex|+Lepidoptera]]

revision.text:
{{Use Pakistani English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox | title = Earthquakes in Pakistan | image = [[File:Sesimic hazard zones of-Pakistan.png|200px]] | caption = Earthquake zones of Pakistan.
'''(<6.0 in green, 6.0–6.9 in blue, 7.0–7.9 in orange, 8.0+ in red)''' ---- | label1 = Largest | data1 = 8.1 [[Moment magnitude scale|Mw]] [[1945 Balochistan earthquake]] | label2 = | data2 = }} [[Pakistan]] is one of the most seismically active countries in the world, being crossed by several major faults. As a result, earthquakes in Pakistan occur often and are destructive. ==Geology== {{main|List of faults in Pakistan|Geology of Pakistan}} Pakistan geologically overlaps both the [[Eurasian Plate|Eurasian]] and [[Indian Plate|Indian]] [[plate tectonics|tectonic plates]]. [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]], the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] and [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] provinces lie on the southern edge of the [[Eurasian plate]] on the [[Iranian Plateau]]. [[Sindh]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] and [[Azad Kashmir|Azad Jammu & Kashmir]] provinces lie on the north-western edge of the Indian plate in [[South Asia]]. Hence this region is prone to violent [[earthquake]]s, as the two tectonic plates collide. ==Earthquakes== {{clr}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" !Date !Locality, district, or province !{{M|mag}} ![[Mercalli intensity scale|MMI]] !Deaths !Injuries !Notes ! |- |2018-01-31 |[[Badakhshan Province]] |6.1 Mw | |1 |9-11 | | |- |[[December 2015 Hindu Kush earthquake|2015-12-25]] |[[Gilgit-Baltistan]]
[[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] |6.3 Mw |V |4 |100 | | |- |[[October 2015 Hindu Kush earthquake|2015-10-26]] |[[Badakhshan Province]] |7.5 Mw |VII |399 |2,536 | |- |[[2014 Pakistan earthquake|2014-05-08]] |[[Sindh]] |4.5 Mw | |2 |50 | | |- |[[2013 Balochistan earthquakes|2013-09-28]] |[[Awaran District]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |6.8 Mw | |400 | | | |- |[[2013 Balochistan earthquakes|2013-09-24]] |[[Awaran District]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |7.7 Mw |VII |825 |700 | | |- |[[2011 Dalbandin earthquake|2011-01-18]] |[[Dalbandin]], [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]] |7.2 Mw |VI |3 |some | | |- |[[2008 Ziarat earthquake|2008-10-29]] |[[Ziarat District]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |6.4 Mw | |215 |200 | | |- |[[2005 Kashmir earthquake|2005-10-08]] |[[Azad Kashmir]] |7.6 Mw |VIII |86,000–87,351 |69,000–75,266 | | |- |1992-05-20 |[[Kohat Division]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|North West Frontier]] |6.0 Mw | |36 |100 |Moderate |{{harvnb|NGDC}} {{citation|title=Stick–slip advance of the Kohat Plateau in Pakistan|url=https://phys.org/news/2012-01-earthquake-pakistan-due-rare-horizontal.html|first=S. P.|last=Satyabala|first2=Zhaohui|last2=Yang|first3=R.|last3=Bilham|year=2012|journal=Nature Geoscience|publisher=Nature Publishing Group|volume=5|pages=147–150|doi=10.1038/ngeo1373}} |- |1983-12-31 |[[Gilgit-Baltistan]] |7.2 Mw |VII |12–26 |60–483 |Severe | {{harvnb|NGDC}} |- |[[1974 Hunza earthquake|1974-12-28]] |[[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] |6.2 Mw | |5,300 |17,000 | | |- |[[1945 Balochistan earthquake|1945-11-28]] |[[Makran Coast]], [[Baluchistan (Chief Commissioner's Province)|British Baluchistan]] |8.1 Mw |X |300–400 | |Tsunami | |- |[[1935 Quetta earthquake|1935-05-31]] |[[Ali Jaan]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |7.7 |X |30,000–60,000 | | | |- |1931-08-27 |Mach, [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |7.4 | | | | | |- |1931-08-24 |Sharigh Valley, [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |7 | | | | | |- |1909-10-21 |[[Sibi]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |7 | |100 | | | {{harvnb|Quittmeyer|Jacob|1979|p=792}} |- |1892-12-20 |[[Qilla Abdullah District|Qilla Abdullah]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |6.8 | | | |[[Chaman Fault]] | |- |1865-01-22 |[[Peshawar]] |6 | | | | | {{harvnb|Quittmeyer|Jacob|1979|p=807}} |- |1852-01-24 |[[Kahan]], [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] |8 | | | | | |- |1827-09-24 |[[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistani province)|Punjab]] |7.8 | |1,000 | | | {{harvnb|Quittmeyer|Jacob|1979|p=806}} |- |[[1819 Rann of Kutch earthquake|1819-06-16]] |[[Allahbund]], Sindh |7.7–8.2 Mw |XI |>1,543 | |Tsunami | |- |1668-05-02 |Shahbandar, Sindh |7.6 | |50,000 | | | {{harvnb|Quittmeyer|Jacob|1979|p=805}} |- class="sortbottom" | colspan="9" style="text-align: center;" |The inclusion criteria for adding events are based on [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Earthquakes|WikiProject Earthquakes]]' [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Earthquakes/notability guidelines|notability guideline]] that was developed for stand alone articles. The principles described are also applicable to lists. In summary, only damaging, injurious, or deadly events should be recorded. |} ==See also== *[[List of faults in Pakistan]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} '''Sources''' {{refbegin}} * {{citation|title=Significant Earthquake Database|url=https://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/form?t=101650&s=1&d=1|author=NGDC|publisher=[[National Geophysical Data Center]], [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|doi=10.7289/V5TD9V7K}} * {{citation|title=Historical and modern seismicity of Pakistan, Afghanistan, northwestern India, and southeastern Iran|url=http://bssa.geoscienceworld.org/content/69/3/773.short|first=R. C.|last=Quittmeyer|first2=K. H.|last2=Jacob|year=1979|journal=Bulletin of the Seismological Society of America|publisher=[[Seismological Society of America]]|volume=69|number=3|pages=773–823}} {{refend}} ==External links== *[https://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1974_12_28.php Northern Pakistan 1974 December 28 12:11:43 UTC Magnitude 6.2 ] [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] accessed Jan 2009 {{Earthquakes in Pakistan}} {{Asia topic|List of earthquakes in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Earthquakes In Pakistan}} [[Category:Earthquakes in Pakistan| ]] [[Category:Lists of events in Pakistan|Earthquakes]] [[Category:Lists of earthquakes by country|Pakistan]]

=====[[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests]]===== *[[Atlantic Dry Forests]] ([[Brazil]])
=====[[Flooded grasslands and savannas]]===== *[[Pantanal]] ([[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Paraguay]])
=====[[Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]]===== *[[Campos rupestres]] ([[Brazil]]) *[[Cerrado]] ([[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Paraguay]]) *[[Humid Chaco]] ([[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Bolivia]], [[Paraguay]])
=====[[Deserts and xeric shrublands]]===== *[[Caatinga]] ([[Brazil]]) *[[Saint Peter and Saint Paul rocks]] ([[Brazil]])
====[[Southern South America]] bioregion==== =====[[Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]]===== *[[Uruguayan savanna]] ([[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Uruguay]])
====Mangroves==== by mangrove complex
=====Amazon-Orinoco-Maranhao complex===== *[[Amapá mangroves]] ([[Brazil]]) *[[Maranhão mangroves]] ([[Brazil]]) *[[Pará mangroves]] ([[Brazil]])
=====Northeast Brazil complex===== *[[Bahia mangroves]] ([[Brazil]]) *[[Rio Piranhas mangroves]] ([[Brazil]]) *[[Rio São Francisco mangroves]] ([[Brazil]])
=====Southeast Brazil complex===== *[[Ilha Grande mangroves]] ([[Brazil]])
==Freshwater ecoregions== ===by freshwater complex=== ====Guiana/Orinoco Complex====
* [[Eastern Morichal]] (Venezuela) * [[Orinoco Delta]] (Venezuela) * [[Southern Orinoco]] (Venezuela) * [[Guiana Watershed]] ([[Brazil]], [[French Guiana]], [[Guyana]], [[Suriname]], Venezuela) ====Amazon Complex====
* [[Amazon Delta]] (Brazil) * [[Amazon Main Channel]] (Brazil, Peru) * [[Northern Amazon Shield Tributaries]] (Brazil) * [[Rio Negro (Amazon)|Rio Negro]] (Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela) * [[Upper Amazon Piedmont]] (Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru) * [[Western Amazon Lowlands]] (Bolivia, Brazil, Peru) * [[Central Brazilian Shield Tributaries]] (Bolivia, Brazil) * [[Tocantins-Araguaia]] (Brazil)
====Northeast Atlantic Complex====
* [[Maranhao]] (Brazil) ====Mata-Atlantica Complex====
* [[Northeast Mata-Atlantica]] (Brazil) * [[East Mata-Atlantica]] (Brazil) * [[Southeast Mata-Atlantica]] (Brazil) ====São Francisco Complex====
* [[São Francisco River|Caatinga]] (Brazil) * [[São Francisco River|Cerrado]] (Brazil) ====Upper Parana Complex====
* [[Alto Paraná Atlantic forests]] (Brazil) ====Beni Savanna (Llanos de Moxos) Complex====
* [[Llanos de Moxos]] (Bolivia, Brazil) ====Paraguay-Parana Complex====
* [[Pantanal]] (Bolivia, Brazil, [[Paraguay]]) * [[Lower Parana]] (Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, [[Uruguay]]) ====Southern Atlantic Complex====
* [[Jacui Highlands]] (Brazil, Uruguay) * [[Lagoa dos Patos Coastal Plain]] (Brazil, Uruguay)
==Marine ecoregions== ''by marine realm and marine province'' ===[[Tropical Atlantic]]=== ====[[North Brazil Shelf]]==== * Guianian * Amazonia
====[[Tropical Southwestern Atlantic]]==== * [[Sao Pedro and Sao Paulo Islands]] * [[Fernando de Noronha and Atol das Rocas]] * Northeastern Brazil * Eastern Brazil * [[Trindade and Martin Vaz Islands]]
===Temperate South America===
====Warm Temperate Southwestern Atlantic==== * Southeastern Brazil * Rio Grande

==References== * Dinerstein, Eric; David Olson; Douglas J. Graham; et al. (1995). ''A Conservation Assessment of the Terrestrial Ecoregions of Latin America and the Caribbean.'' World Bank, Washington DC, [http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/957541468270313045/pdf/multi-page.pdf]. * Olson, D., Dinerstein, E., Canevari, P., Davidson, I., Castro, G., Morisset, V., Abell, R., and Toledo, E.; eds. (1998). ''Freshwater Biodiversity of Latin America and the Caribbean: A Conservation Assessment.'' Biodiversity Support Program, Washington DC, [https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/part/137774]. * Spalding, Mark D., Helen E. Fox, Gerald R. Allen, Nick Davidson ''et al.'' "Marine Ecoregions of the World: A Bioregionalization of Coastal and Shelf Areas". ''Bioscience'' Vol. 57 No. 7, July/August 2007, pp. 573-583, [http://algae.thu.edu.tw/lab/2013_Meeting_FebJune/2007_Marine_ecoregions_of_the_world.pdf].
